Variance Reduced ProxSkip: Algorithm, Theory
and Application to Federated Learning

Grigory Malinovsky
KAUST
grigory.malinovsky@kaust.edu.sa    Kai Yi
KAUST
kai.yi@kaust.edu.sa    Peter Richtárik
KAUST
peter.richtarik@kaust.edu.sa
(May 26, 2022
(revised on July 9, 2022))
Abstract

We study distributed optimization methods based on the local training (LT) paradigm: achieving communication efficiency by performing richer local gradient-based training on the clients before parameter averaging. Looking back at the progress of the field, we identify 5 generations of LT methods: 1) heuristic, 2) homogeneous, 3) sublinear, 4) linear, and 5) accelerated. The 5th generation, initiated by the ProxSkip method of Mishchenko et al. [2022] and its analysis, is characterized by the first theoretical confirmation that LT is a communication acceleration mechanism. Inspired by this recent progress, we contribute to the 5th generation of LT methods by showing that it is possible to enhance them further using variance reduction. While all previous theoretical results for LT methods ignore the cost of local work altogether, and are framed purely in terms of the number of communication rounds, we show that our methods can be substantially faster in terms of the total training cost than the state-of-the-art method ProxSkip in theory and practice in the regime when local computation is sufficiently expensive. We characterize this threshold theoretically, and confirm our theoretical predictions with empirical results.

1 Introduction

Announced in April 2017 in a Google AI blog [McMahan and Ramage, 2017], and citing four foundational papers [Konečný et al., 2016b, a, McMahan et al., 2017, Bonawitz et al., 2017] of what was to become a new and rapidly growing interdisciplinary field, federated learning (FL) constitutes a novel paradigm for training supervised machine learning models. The key idea is the acknowledgement that increasing amounts of data are being captured and stored on edge devices, such as mobile phones, sensors and hospital workstations, and that moving the data to a datacenter for centralized processing may be infeasible or undesirable for various reasons, including high energy costs and data privacy concerns [Kairouz et al., 2019, Li et al., 2020a]. FL faces a multitude of challenges which are being actively addressed by the research community.

1.1 Formalism

We study the standard optimization formulation of federated learning [Konečný et al., 2016a, McMahan et al., 2017, Kairouz et al., 2019, Wang et al., 2021] given by

minx∈ℝd′⁡ϕ​(x),ϕ​(x)≔∑i=1Mnin​ϕi​(x),ϕi​(x)≔1ni​∑j=1niϕi​j​(x),formulae-sequence≔subscript𝑥superscriptℝsuperscript𝑑′italic-ϕ𝑥italic-ϕ𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑥≔subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑥1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑥\min\limits_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime}}}\phi(x),\qquad\phi(x)\coloneqq\sum\limits_{i=1}^{M}\frac{n_{i}}{n}\phi_{i}(x),\qquad\phi_{i}(x)\coloneqq\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\phi_{ij}(x), (1)

where M𝑀M is the number of clients (devices, machines, workers), nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} is the number of training data points on client i∈{1,2,…,M}𝑖12…𝑀i\in\{1,2,\dots,M\}, and n≔∑i=1Mni≔𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑛𝑖n\coloneqq\sum_{i=1}^{M}n_{i} is the total number of training data points collectively owned by this federation of M𝑀M clients. Note that ϕitalic-ϕ\phi is the empirical risk over the federated dataset. Perhaps conceptually the simplest method for solving (1) is gradient descent (GD),

xt+1=xt−γ​∇ϕ​(xt)=xt−γ​∑i=1Mnin​∇ϕi​(xt)=∑i=1Mnin​(xt−γ​∇ϕi​(xt)),subscript𝑥𝑡1subscript𝑥𝑡𝛾∇italic-ϕsubscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥𝑡𝛾superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛∇subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑥𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛subscript𝑥𝑡𝛾∇subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑥𝑡x_{t+1}=x_{t}-\gamma\nabla\phi(x_{t})=x_{t}-\gamma\sum\limits_{i=1}^{M}\frac{n_{i}}{n}\nabla\phi_{i}(x_{t})=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{M}\frac{n_{i}}{n}\left(x_{t}-\gamma\nabla\phi_{i}(x_{t})\right), (2)

where γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 is the stepsize. It will be useful to describe how GD would be implemented in a federated environment. First, all clients i∈{1,…,M}𝑖1…𝑀i\in\{1,\dots,M\} in parallel perform a single local gradient step starting from the current global model xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t}, arriving at the local models xi​t≔xt−γ​∇ϕi​(xt)≔subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥𝑡𝛾∇subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑥𝑡x_{it}\coloneqq x_{t}-\gamma\nabla\phi_{i}(x_{t}), i∈{1,…,M}𝑖1…𝑀i\in\{1,\dots,M\}. These local models are then communicated to the orchestrating server, which aggregates them via weighted averaging, arriving at the new global model xt+1=∑i=1Mnin​xi​tsubscript𝑥𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{t+1}=\sum_{i=1}^{M}\frac{n_{i}}{n}x_{it}. This new model is then broadcast back to all clients, and the process is repeated until a model of sufficient quality is found.

1.2 Federated averaging

Proposed by Povey et al. [2015], Moritz et al. [2016], McMahan et al. [2017], federated averaging (FedAvg) is arguably the most popular method for solving the standard FL formulation (1). Motivated by the specific constraints of federated environments, FedAvg can be seen as a practical enhancement of GD via the simultaneous application of three techniques: a) data sampling (DS), b) client sampling (CS), and c) local training (LT). That is,

FedAvg = GD + (DS + CS + LT).FedAvg = GD + (DS + CS + LT)\text{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}FedAvg} = {\sf\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}GD} + (DS + CS + LT)}.

We will now briefly describe each of these three GD-enhancing techniques separately.

  • (a)

    GD + Data Sampling. In situations when the local datasets are so large that the computation of the exact local gradients becomes a bottleneck, it makes sense to approximate them via data sampling. That is, instead of passing through all local data to compute the local gradient ∇ϕi​(xt)∇subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑥𝑡\nabla\phi_{i}(x_{t}), each client i𝑖i computes the gradients ∇ϕi​j​(xt)∇subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗subscript𝑥𝑡\nabla\phi_{ij}(x_{t}) for j∈𝒟i​t𝑗subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡j\in\mathcal{D}_{it} only, where 𝒟i​tsubscript𝒟𝑖𝑡\mathcal{D}_{it} is a suitably chosen small-enough subset of the local dataset {1,…,ni}1…subscript𝑛𝑖\{1,\dots,n_{i}\}. These gradients are then used to form gradient estimators gi​(xt)≈∇ϕi​(xt)subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝑥𝑡∇subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑥𝑡g_{i}(x_{t})\approx\nabla\phi_{i}(x_{t}) which are used to perform a local SGD step on all clients. The rest of the procedure is the same as in the case of GD. That is, the local models obtained in this way are sent to the orchestrating server, the server aggregates them via weighted averaging and broadcasts the resulting model back to all clients. Combination of GD and DS can be seen as a particular version of SGD, where the stochastic gradient estimator is formed from the gradients ∇ϕi​j​(xt)∇subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗subscript𝑥𝑡\nabla\phi_{ij}(x_{t}) associated with the datapoints (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) where j∈∪i=1M𝒟i​t𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡j\in\cup_{i=1}^{M}\mathcal{D}_{it}. While DS is still an active area of research, it has been studied for a long time, and is in general well understood [Takáč et al., 2013, Li et al., 2014, Csiba and Richtárik, 2018, Gower et al., 2019a, Horváth and Richtárik, 2019, Khaled and Richtárik, 2020].

  • (b)

    GD + Client Sampling. In practical federated environments, and especially in cross-device FL [Kairouz et al., 2019], the number of clients is enormous, they are not all available at all times, and the orchestrating server has limited compute and memory capacity. For these and other reasons, practical FL methods need to work in an environment in which a small subset 𝒮t⊆{1,…,M}subscript𝒮𝑡1…𝑀\mathcal{S}_{t}\subseteq\{1,\dots,M\} of the clients is sampled (“participates”) in each communication/aggregation/training round only. Since only the participating clients i∈𝒮t𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡i\in\mathcal{S}_{t} perform a local GD step and communicate the resulting local model to the orchestrating server for aggregation, this induces an error compared to GD, which has an adverse effect on the convergence rate. Combination of GD and CS can be seen as a particular version of SGD, where the stochastic gradient estimator is formed from the gradients ∇ϕi​j​(xt)∇subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗subscript𝑥𝑡\nabla\phi_{ij}(x_{t}) associated with the datapoints (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) where j∈∪i=1𝒮t{1,…,ni}𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝒮𝑡1…subscript𝑛𝑖j\in\cup_{i=1}^{\mathcal{S}_{t}}\{1,\dots,n_{i}\}. While CS is still an active area of research, since CS is a special type of DS, much was known about CS long before FedAvg was proposed [Gower et al., 2019a, Horváth and Richtárik, 2019]. Still, CS poses new challenges tackled by the community Eichner et al. [2019], Chen et al. [2020], Gower et al. [2019a], Cho et al. [2020], Charles et al. [2021].

  • (c)

    GD + Local Training. In federated learning, the cost of communication between the clients and the orchestrating server forms the key bottleneck. Indeed, in their FedAvg paper, which introduced LT to the world of federated learning, McMahan et al. [2017] wrote:

    “In contrast111to datacenter optimization, in federated optimization communication costs dominate”.

    LT is a conceptually simple and surprisingly powerful communication-acceleration technique. The basic idea behind LT is for the clients to perform multiple local GD steps instead of a single step (which is how GD operates) before communication and aggregation takes place. The intuitive reasoning used in virtually all papers on this topic is: performing multiple local GD steps results in “richer” and ultimately more useful local training in the sense that fewer communication rounds will hopefully suffice to finish the training. McMahan et al. [2017] supported this intuition with ample empirical evidence, and credited LT as the critical component behind the success of FedAvg:

    “Thus, our goal is to use additional computation in order to decrease the number of rounds of communication needed to train a model…” “Communication costs are the principal constraint, and we show a reduction in required communication rounds by 10–100×\times as compared to synchronized stochastic gradient descent.” “…the speedups we achieve are due primarily to adding more computation on each client”.

2 Five Generations of Local Training Methods

We now offer several historical comments on the most important developments related to the theoretical understanding of LT. To this end, we have identified 5 distinct generations of LT methods, each with its unique challenges and characteristics. To make the narrative simple, and since we focus on this regime in our paper, we limit our overview to loss functions ϕisubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖\phi_{i} that are μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex and L𝐿L-smooth. This is arguably the most studied class of functions in continuous optimization [Nesterov, 2004], and for this reason, it presents a valuable litmus test for any theory of LT.

2.1 Generation 1: Heuristic Age

While LT ideas were used in several machine learning domains before [Povey et al., 2015, Moritz et al., 2016], LT truly rose to prominence as a practically potent communication acceleration technique due to the seminal paper of McMahan et al. [2017] which introduced the FedAvg algorithm. However, no theory was provided in their work, nor in any prior work. LT-based heuristics, i.e., methods without any theoretical guarantees, dominated the initial development of the field up to, and including, the FedAvg paper.

2.2 Generation 2: Homogeneous Age

The first theoretical results for LT methods offering explicit convergence rates relied on various data/gradient homogeneity222We use the term homogeneity to refer to various related assumptions used in the literature, including bounded gradient norms [Li et al., 2020b], bounded gradient variance [Li et al., 2019, Yu et al., 2019] and bounded gradient diversity [Haddadpour and Mahdavi, 2019]. assumptions. The intuitive rationale behind such assumptions comes from the following thought process. In the extreme case when all the local functions ϕisubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖\phi_{i} are identical (this is often referred to as the homogeneous or i.i.d. data regime), there is a very simple approach to making GD communication-efficient: push the idea of LT to its extreme by running GD on all clients, independently and in parallel, without any communication/synchronization/averaging whatsoever. Extrapolating from this, it is reasonable to assume that as we increase heterogeneity, taking multiple local steps should still be beneficial as long as we do not take too many steps. Several authors analyzed various LT methods under such assumptions, and obtained rates [Haddadpour and Mahdavi, 2019, Yu et al., 2019, Li et al., 2019, 2020b]. However, bounded dissimilarity assumptions are highly problematic. First, they do not seem to be satisfied even for some of the simplest function classes, such as strongly convex quadratics [Khaled et al., 2019, 2020], and moreover, it is well known that practical FL datasets are highly heterogeneous/non-i.i.d. McMahan et al. [2017], Kairouz et al. [2019]. So, analyses relying on such strong assumptions are both mathematically questionable, and practically irrelevant.

2.3 Generation 3: Sublinear Age

The third generation of LT methods is characterized by the successful removal of the bounded dissimilarity assumptions from the convergence theory. Khaled et al. [2019] first achieved this breakthrough by studying the simplest LT method: local gradient descent (LGD) (i.e., a simple combination of GD and LT). While works belonging to this generation elevated LT to the same theoretical footing as GD in terms of the assumptions, which marked an important milestone in our understanding of LT, unfortunately, the obtained communication complexity theory of LGD is pessimistic when compared to vanilla GD. Indeed, the inclusion of LT did not lead to an improvement upon the communication complexity of vanilla GD. Moreover, while GD enjoys a linear communication complexity (in the smooth and strongly convex regime), the communication complexity of LGD is sublinear. In a follow-up work, Khaled et al. [2020] later analyzed LGD in combination with DS as well. Woodworth et al. [2020] and Glasgow et al. [2022] provided lower bounds for LGD with DS showing that it is not better than minibatch SGD in heterogeneous setting. See the work of Malinovsky et al. [2020] for a fixed-point theory viewpoint.

2.4 Generation 4: Linear Age

The fourth generation of LT methods is characterized by the effort to design linearly converging variants of LT algorithms. In order to achieve this, it was important to tame the adverse effect of the so-called client drift [Karimireddy et al., 2020], which was identified as the culprit of the worse-than-GD theoretical performance of the previous generation of LT methods. The first LT-based method that successfully tamed client drift, and as a result obtained a linear convergence rate, was Scaffold [Karimireddy et al., 2020]. Several alternative approaches to obtaining the same effect were later proposed by Gorbunov et al. [2020a] and Mitra et al. [2021] . While obtaining a linear rate for LT methods under standard assumptions was a major achievement, the communication complexity of these methods is still somewhat worse333Both GD, and LT methods such as Scaffold [Karimireddy et al., 2020], S-Local-GD [Gorbunov et al., 2020a] and FedLin [Mitra et al., 2021] enjoy the linear rate 𝒪​(κ​log⁡1ε)𝒪𝜅1𝜀\mathcal{O}(\kappa\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}), where κ𝜅\kappa is a condition number. However, this condition number is in general slightly worse for the LT methods. than that of vanilla GD, and is at best equal to that of GD.

2.5 Generation 5: Accelerated Age

Finally, the fifth generation of LT methods was initiated recently by Mishchenko et al. [2022] with their ProxSkip method which enjoys accelerated communication complexity. Acceleration comes from the LT steps coupled with a new client drift reduction technique and a probabilistic approach to deciding whether communication takes place or not. Mishchenko et al. [2022] first reformulate (1) into the equivalent consensus form

minx∈ℝd⁡f​(x)+r​(x),subscript𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑𝑓𝑥𝑟𝑥\min_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(x)+r(x), (3)

where d=M​d′𝑑𝑀superscript𝑑′d=Md^{\prime}, x=(x1,…,xM)∈ℝd𝑥subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑀superscriptℝ𝑑x=(x_{1},\dots,x_{M})\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, and

f​(x)≔∑i=1Mnni​ϕi​(xi),r​(x)={0 if ​x1=⋯=xM,+∞ otherwise.formulae-sequence≔𝑓𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀𝑛subscript𝑛𝑖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝑟𝑥cases0 if subscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑀 otherwise.f(x)\coloneqq\sum\limits_{i=1}^{M}\frac{n}{n_{i}}\phi_{i}(x_{i}),\qquad r(x)=\begin{cases}0&\text{ if }x_{1}=\dots=x_{M},\\ +\infty&\text{ otherwise.}\end{cases} (4)

The ProxSkip method is a randomized variant of proximal gradient descent (ProxGD) [Nesterov, 2013, Beck, 2017] for solving (3), with the proximity operator of r𝑟r, given by

proxr⁡(x)≔arg⁡miny⁡(r​(y)+12​‖y−x‖2),≔subscriptprox𝑟𝑥subscript𝑦𝑟𝑦12superscriptnorm𝑦𝑥2\operatorname{prox}_{r}(x)\coloneqq\arg\min_{y}\left(r(y)+\frac{1}{2}\|y-x\|^{2}\right),

being evaluated in each iteration with probability p∈(0,1]𝑝01p\in(0,1] only. Remarkably, Mishchenko et al. [2022] showed that it is possible to choose p𝑝p as low as 1/κ1𝜅1/\sqrt{\kappa}, where κ𝜅\kappa is the condition number of f𝑓f, without this worsening the rate of its parent method ProxGD. In summary, ProxSkip lets the M𝑀M clients perform κ𝜅\sqrt{\kappa} local gradient steps in expectation, followed by the evaluation of the prox of r𝑟r, which in the case of the consensus reformulation of (1) means averaging across all M𝑀M nodes, i.e., communication.

3 ProxSkip-VR: A General Variance Reduction Framework for ProxSkip

In this work we contribute to the fifth generation of LT methods by extending the work of Mishchenko et al. [2022] to allow for a very large family of gradient estimators, including variance reduced (VR) ones [Johnson and Zhang, 2013, Defazio et al., 2014, Kovalev et al., 2020a, Mishchenko et al., 2019].

Like ProxSkip, our method ProxSkip-VR (Algorithm 1) is aimed to solve the composite problem (3) in a more general setting (see Assumptions 1–3), with the special structure (4) coming from the consensus reformulation being a special case only. Our method differs from ProxSkip in that we replace the gradient ∇f​(xt)∇𝑓subscript𝑥𝑡\nabla f(x_{t}) by an unbiased estimator gt=g​(xt,yt,ξt)subscript𝑔𝑡𝑔subscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑦𝑡subscript𝜉𝑡g_{t}=g(x_{t},{\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}y_{t}},\xi_{t}), where ξtsubscript𝜉𝑡\xi_{t} is the source of randomness controlling unbiasedness and ytsubscript𝑦𝑡y_{t} is a control vector whose role is to progressively reduce the variance of the estimator, so that

𝔼​[gt|xt,yt]=∇f​(xt).𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝑔𝑡subscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑦𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝑥𝑡\mathbb{E}\left[g_{t}\;|\;x_{t},{\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}y_{t}}\right]=\nabla f(x_{t}).

There are several motivations behind this endeavor. First, it is a-priori not clear whether the novel proof technique employed by Mishchenko et al. [2022] can be combined with the proof techniques used in the analysis of VR methods, and hence it is scientifically significant to investigate the possibility of such a merger of two strands of the literature. We show that this is possible. Second, marrying VR estimators with ProxSkip can lead to novel system architectures which are more elaborate than the simplistic client-server architecture (see Section 4). Lastly, while researchers contributing to generations 1–4 of LT methods were preoccupied with trying to close the gap on GD in terms of communication efficiency, they ignored the number of the local steps appearing in their algorithms, and reported their bounds primarily in terms of the number of communication rounds. Bounds reported this way make complete sense in the scenario when the cost of local work (e.g., one SGD step w.r.t. a single data point), say δ𝛿\delta, is negligible compared to the cost of communication, which can w.l.o.g. assume to be 1, and when the number of local steps is small. With the advent of the fifth generation of LT methods, we can (to a large degree) stop worrying about communication efficiency, and can now ask more refined questions, such as:

Are there gradient estimators which, when combined with ProxSkip, lead to faster algorithms in terms of the total cost, which includes the communication cost as well as the cost of local training?

We give an affirmative answer to the question in Sections 4 and 5.

3.1 Standard assumptions

We assume throughout that f𝑓f is differentiable, and let Df​(x,y)≔f​(x)−f​(y)−⟨∇f​(y),x−y⟩≔subscript𝐷𝑓𝑥𝑦𝑓𝑥𝑓𝑦∇𝑓𝑦𝑥𝑦D_{f}(x,y)\coloneqq f(x)-f(y)-\langle\nabla f(y),x-y\rangle denote the Bregman divergence of f𝑓f. Throughout the work we make the following assumptions:

Assumption 1 (L𝐿L-smoothness).

There exists L>0𝐿0L>0 such that 2​Df​(x,y)≤L​‖x−y‖22subscript𝐷𝑓𝑥𝑦𝐿superscriptnorm𝑥𝑦22D_{f}(x,y)\leq L\left\|x-y\right\|^{2} for all x,y∈ℝd𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Assumption 2 (μ𝜇\mu-convexity).

There exists μ>0𝜇0\mu>0 such that μ​‖x−y‖2≤2​Df​(x,y)𝜇superscriptnorm𝑥𝑦22subscript𝐷𝑓𝑥𝑦\mu\left\|x-y\right\|^{2}\leq 2D_{f}(x,y) for all x,y∈ℝd𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Assumption 3.

The regularizer r:ℝd→ℝ∪{+∞}:𝑟→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝr:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}\cup\{+\infty\} is proper, closed and convex.

Under the above assumptions, (3) has a unique minimizer x⋆subscript𝑥⋆x_{\star}. Let h⋆≔∇f​(x⋆)≔subscriptℎ⋆∇𝑓subscript𝑥⋆h_{\star}\coloneqq\nabla f(x_{\star}).

3.2 Modelling variance reduced gradient estimators

Our next assumption, initially introduced by Gorbunov et al. [2020b], postulates several parametric inequalities characterizing the behavior and ultimately the quality of a gradient estimator. Similar assumptions appeared later in [Gorbunov et al., 2020a, c].

Assumption 4.

4 New FL Architecture: Regional Hubs Connecting the Clients to the Server

We now illustrate the versatility of our ProxSkip-VR framework by designing a new “FL architecture” and proposing an algorithm that can efficiently operate in this setting.

In particular, we consider the situation where the clients are clustered (e.g., based on region), and where a hub is placed in between each cluster and the central server. Clients communicate with their regional hub only, which can communicate with the central server (see Figure 1). There are M𝑀M hubs, hub i𝑖i handles nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} clients, and client j𝑗j associated with hub i𝑖i owns loss function ϕi​jsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗\phi_{ij}.

Mathematically, this can be modeled by problem (1). In this situation, we care about two sources of communication cost: the server and the hubs, and between the hubs and the clients. We propose to handle this via local training (LT) between the server and the hubs, and via client sampling (CS) and compressed communication (CC) between the hubs and the clients. Algorithmically, from the server-hubs perspective, we are applying a particular variant of ProxSkip-VR to (3)–(4), where ϕisubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖\phi_{i} is the aggregate loss handles by hub i𝑖i. This takes care of communication efficiency between the server and the hub. Note also that we need not worry about partial participation of hubs, as these are designed to be always available. However, in this situation, it is costly for hub i𝑖i to compute the gradient of ϕisubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖\phi_{i} as this involves communication with all the clients it handles.

4.1 Handling of client sampling (CS) and compressed communication (CC)

In order to alleviate this burden, we propose a combination of CS and CC. However, we need to be very careful about how to do this. Indeed, both CS and CC, even when applied in isolation, and without ProxSkip in the mix, can lead to a substantial slowdown in convergence. For example, one will typically lose linear convergence in the strongly convex regime. However, techniques for preserving linear convergence in the presence of CS and CC exist: this is what variance reduction strategies are designed to do. For example, LSVRG [Hofmann et al., 2015, Kovalev et al., 2020a] is a VR technique for reducing the variance due to CS, and DIANA [Mishchenko et al., 2019] is a VR technique for reducing the variance due to CC. However, we are not aware of any VR method that combines CS (applied first) and CC (applied second).

We now propose such a technique. In iteration t𝑡t, every hub i∈{1,2,…,M}𝑖12…𝑀i\in\{1,2,\dots,M\} selects a random subset 𝒮ti⊆{1,2,…,ni}superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑡𝑖12…subscript𝑛𝑖\mathcal{S}_{t}^{i}\subseteq\{1,2,\dots,n_{i}\} of the clients it handles of cardinality τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i}, chosen uniformly at random, and estimates the hub gradient via

∇ϕi​(xt)≈gti≔1|𝒮ti|​∑j∈𝒮ti𝒬ti​j​(∇ϕi​j​(xt)−∇ϕi​j​(yt))+∇ϕi​(yt),∇subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑥𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑡𝑖≔1superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑡𝑖subscript𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒬𝑡𝑖𝑗∇subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗subscript𝑥𝑡∇subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗subscript𝑦𝑡∇subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑦𝑡\nabla\phi_{i}(x_{t})\approx g_{t}^{i}\coloneqq\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}_{t}^{i}|}\sum\limits_{j\in\mathcal{S}_{t}^{i}}\mathcal{Q}_{t}^{ij}\left(\nabla\phi_{ij}(x_{t})-\nabla\phi_{ij}(y_{t})\right)+\nabla\phi_{i}(y_{t}), (11)

where 𝒬ti​j:ℝd′→ℝd′:superscriptsubscript𝒬𝑡𝑖𝑗→superscriptℝsuperscript𝑑′superscriptℝsuperscript𝑑′\mathcal{Q}_{t}^{ij}:\mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime}}\to\mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime}} is a randomized compression (e.g., sparsification or quantization) operator [Alistarh et al., 2017, Khirirat et al., 2018, Horváth et al., 2019b, a, Philippenko and Dieuleveut, 2020], i.e., a mapping satisfying

𝔼​[Qti​j​(x)]=x,𝔼​[‖Qti​j​(x)−x‖2]≤ω​‖x‖2,∀x∈ℝd′,formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑡𝑖𝑗𝑥𝑥formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝑡𝑖𝑗𝑥𝑥2𝜔superscriptnorm𝑥2for-all𝑥superscriptℝsuperscript𝑑′\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{t}^{ij}(x)\right]=x,\quad\mathbb{E}\left[\|Q_{t}^{ij}(x)-x\|^{2}\right]\leq\omega\left\|x\right\|^{2},\quad\forall x\in\mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime}}, (12)

and the control vector ytsubscript𝑦𝑡y_{t} is updated probabilistically as follows:

yt+1={xt with probability qyt with probability 1−q.subscript𝑦𝑡1casessubscript𝑥𝑡 with probability 𝑞subscript𝑦𝑡 with probability 1𝑞y_{t+1}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{lll}x_{t}&\text{ with probability }&q\\ y_{t}&\text{ with probability }&1-q\end{array}\right.. (13)

The global gradient estimator (a vector in ℝM​d′superscriptℝ𝑀superscript𝑑′\mathbb{R}^{Md^{\prime}}), which we call HUB, is construcuted as a concatenation of the above hub estimators:

∇f​(xt)≔(nin​∇ϕi​(xt))i=1M≈gt≔g​(xt,yt,ξt)≔(nin​gti)i=1M,≔∇𝑓subscript𝑥𝑡superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖𝑛∇subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑥𝑡𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑔𝑡≔𝑔subscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑦𝑡subscript𝜉𝑡≔superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑡𝑖𝑖1𝑀\nabla f(x_{t})\coloneqq\left(\frac{n_{i}}{n}\nabla\phi_{i}(x_{t})\right)_{i=1}^{M}\approx g_{t}\coloneqq g(x_{t},y_{t},\xi_{t})\coloneqq\left(\frac{n_{i}}{n}g_{t}^{i}\right)_{i=1}^{M}, (14)

where ξtsubscript𝜉𝑡\xi_{t} represents the combined randomness from the compressors {𝒬ti​j}superscriptsubscript𝒬𝑡𝑖𝑗\{\mathcal{Q}_{t}^{ij}\} and random sets {𝒮ti}superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑡𝑖\{\mathcal{S}_{t}^{i}\}.

In order to analyze ProxSkip-VR in the consensus form, from now on we assume that ni=m=n/Msubscript𝑛𝑖𝑚𝑛𝑀n_{i}=m=\nicefrac{{n}}{{M}} and τi=τ∈{1,2,…,m}subscript𝜏𝑖𝜏12…𝑚\tau_{i}=\tau\in\{1,2,\dots,m\} for all i𝑖i, and rely on a slightly different, more general reformulation:

minx∈ℝd⁡1m​∑j=1mϕ~j​(x)+r​(x),ϕ~j​(x)≔1M​∑i=1Mϕi​j​(xi),r​(x)≔{0 if ​x1=⋯=xM,+∞ otherwise.formulae-sequence≔subscript𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript~italic-ϕ𝑗𝑥𝑟𝑥subscript~italic-ϕ𝑗𝑥1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗subscript𝑥𝑖≔𝑟𝑥cases0 if subscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑀 otherwise.\min\limits_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\frac{1}{m}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{m}\widetilde{\phi}_{j}(x)+r(x),\quad\widetilde{\phi}_{j}(x)\coloneqq\frac{1}{M}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{M}\phi_{ij}\left(x_{i}\right),\quad r(x)\coloneqq\begin{cases}0&\text{ if }x_{1}=\cdots=x_{M},\\ +\infty&\text{ otherwise.}\end{cases}

Our proposed method ProxSkip-HUB is ProxSkip-VR combined with the novel HUB estimator (14), applied to the above reformulation; see Algorithm 2.

4.2 Theory for ProxSkip-HUB

In the following result we first claim that the above estimator satisfies Assumption 4 with C=C~=0𝐶~𝐶0C=\tilde{C}=0 (i.e., it is variance-reduced), and the rest of the claim follows by application of our general theorem Theorem 5.

Theorem 9.

Set W=2​B/(1−B~)𝑊2𝐵1~𝐵W=\nicefrac{{2B}}{{(1-\tilde{B})}} and 0<γ≤min⁡{1/μ,1/(A+W​A~)}.0𝛾1𝜇1𝐴𝑊~𝐴0<\gamma\leq\min\left\{\nicefrac{{1}}{{\mu}},\nicefrac{{1}}{{(A+W\tilde{A})}}\right\}. Then the iterates of ProxSkip-VR for any p∈(0,1]𝑝01p\in(0,1] satisfy

𝔼​[ΨT]≤max⁡{(1−γ​μ)T,(1−p2)T,(1−q2)T}​Ψ0,𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΨ𝑇superscript1𝛾𝜇𝑇superscript1superscript𝑝2𝑇superscript1𝑞2𝑇subscriptΨ0\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\Psi_{T}\right]\leq\max\left\{(1-\gamma\mu)^{T},(1-p^{2})^{T},\left(1-\frac{q}{2}\right)^{T}\right\}\Psi_{0},

where the Lyapunov function is defined by

Ψt≔‖xt−x⋆‖2+γ2p2​‖ht−h⋆‖2+γ2​8q​(1+ωτ)​σt.≔subscriptΨ𝑡superscriptnormsubscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆2superscript𝛾2superscript𝑝2superscriptnormsubscriptℎ𝑡subscriptℎ⋆2superscript𝛾28𝑞1𝜔𝜏subscript𝜎𝑡\Psi_{t}\coloneqq\|x_{t}-x_{\star}\|^{2}+\frac{\gamma^{2}}{p^{2}}\|h_{t}-h_{\star}\|^{2}+\gamma^{2}\frac{8}{q}\left(1+\frac{\omega}{\tau}\right)\sigma_{t}.

We now consider two special cases. In the first, we specialize to the no compression regime, and in the second, to the full participation regime.

Corollary 1 (No compression).

If we do not use compression (i.e., ω=0𝜔0\omega=0), then the communication and iteration complexities are

#​c​o​m​m​s=𝒪​(Lmaxμ​log⁡1ε),#​i​t​e​r​s=𝒪​(Lmaxμ​log⁡1ε),formulae-sequence#𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑚𝑠𝒪subscript𝐿𝜇1𝜀#𝑖𝑡𝑒𝑟𝑠𝒪subscript𝐿𝜇1𝜀\#comms=\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{L_{\max}}{\mu}}\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right),\qquad\#iters=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{L_{\max}}{\mu}\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right),

respectively. However, if we use the estimator (11) in Theorem 5 directly, then the communication and iteration complexities are

#​c​o​m​m​s=𝒪​(L​(τ)μ​log⁡1ε),#​i​t​e​r​s=𝒪​(L​(τ)μ​log⁡1ε),formulae-sequence#𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑚𝑠𝒪𝐿𝜏𝜇1𝜀#𝑖𝑡𝑒𝑟𝑠𝒪𝐿𝜏𝜇1𝜀\#comms=\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{L(\tau)}{\mu}}\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right),\qquad\#iters=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{L(\tau)}{\mu}\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right),

where L​(τ)≔m−ττ​(m−1)​Lmax+m​(τ−1)τ​(m−1)​L≔𝐿𝜏𝑚𝜏𝜏𝑚1subscript𝐿𝑚𝜏1𝜏𝑚1𝐿L(\tau)\coloneqq\frac{m-\tau}{\tau(m-1)}L_{\max}+\frac{m(\tau-1)}{\tau(m-1)}L.

Notice that Lmax≥Lsubscript𝐿𝐿L_{\max}\geq L, and that L​(τ)=Lmax𝐿𝜏subscript𝐿L(\tau)=L_{\max} for τ=1𝜏1\tau=1 and L​(τ)=L𝐿𝜏𝐿L(\tau)=L for τ=m𝜏𝑚\tau=m. Moreover, L​(τ)𝐿𝜏L(\tau) decreases as the minibatch size τ𝜏\tau increases.

Corollary 2 (No client sampling).

If we do not use client sampling (i.e., τ=m𝜏𝑚\tau=m), then the communication and iteration complexities are

#​c​o​m​m​s=𝒪​(Lmaxμ​(1+ωM)​log⁡1ε),#​i​t​e​r​s=𝒪​(Lmaxμ​(1+ωM)​log⁡1ε),formulae-sequence#𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑚𝑠𝒪subscript𝐿𝜇1𝜔𝑀1𝜀#𝑖𝑡𝑒𝑟𝑠𝒪subscript𝐿𝜇1𝜔𝑀1𝜀\#comms=\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{L_{\max}}{\mu}\left(1+\frac{\omega}{M}\right)}\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right),\qquad\#iters=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{L_{\max}}{\mu}\left(1+\frac{\omega}{M}\right)\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right),

respectively.

Assume r​(x)≡0𝑟𝑥0r(x)\equiv 0. If 𝒬ti​j​(x)≡xsuperscriptsubscript𝒬𝑡𝑖𝑗𝑥𝑥\mathcal{Q}_{t}^{ij}(x)\equiv x, then ω=0𝜔0\omega=0, and we restore the well-known LSVRG method [Hofmann et al., 2015, Kovalev et al., 2020b], assuming that the functions ϕi​jsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗\phi_{ij} have the same smoothness constant. We can recover the same rate exactly as well, but with a slightly more refined analysis, one in which we do not need to work with compressors (LSVRG does not involve any), which makes for a tighter analysis. On the other hand, if τ=m𝜏𝑚\tau=m, we restore the rate of the well-known DIANA [Mishchenko et al., 2019, Horváth et al., 2019b] method and its sibling Rand-DIANA [Shulgin and Richtárik, 2021].

5 Experiments

To illustrate the predictive power of our theory, it suffices to consider L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-regularized logistic regression in the distributed setting (1), with

ϕi​(x)=1ni​∑j=1nilog⁡(1+exp⁡(−bi​j​ai​j⊤​x))+λ2​‖x‖2,subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑥1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑖1subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗top𝑥𝜆2superscriptnorm𝑥2\phi_{i}(x)=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\log\left(1+\exp\left(-b_{ij}a_{ij}^{\top}x\right)\right)+\frac{\lambda}{2}\|x\|^{2},

where nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} is the number of data points per worker ai​j∈ℝd′subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗superscriptℝsuperscript𝑑′a_{ij}\in\mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime}} and bi​j∈{−1,+1}subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗11b_{ij}\in\{-1,+1\} are the data samples and labels. We choose ni=m=n/Msubscript𝑛𝑖𝑚𝑛𝑀n_{i}=m=\nicefrac{{n}}{{M}} for all i𝑖i. We set the regularization parameter λ=5⋅10−4​L𝜆⋅5superscript104𝐿\lambda=5\cdot 10^{-4}L by default, where L𝐿L is the smoothness constant of f𝑓f. We conduct several experiments on the w8a dataset from LibSVM library [Chang and Lin, 2011].

5.1 ProxSkip-LSVRG vs baselines

In Figure 2 (first row), we compare various LT baselines444With the exception of LocalSGD, all use client drift correction. for three choices of mini-batch sizes (τ=16,32,64𝜏163264\tau=16,32,64) with our method ProxSkip-VR combined with the LSVRG estimator, which is a special case of the HUB estimator when 𝒬ti​j​(x)≡xsuperscriptsubscript𝒬𝑡𝑖𝑗𝑥𝑥\mathcal{Q}_{t}^{ij}(x)\equiv x for all i,j𝑖𝑗i,j. We see that our method outperforms all other methods significantly due to its communication-acceleration properties.

5.2 The total cost of ProxSkip-LSVRG can be significantly smaller than the total cost of ProxSkip, in theory and practice

Next, we derive the total cost, which includes communication cost (assumed to be 111, for normalization purposes), and computational cost (assumed to be δ𝛿\delta; and equal to the cost of performing one SGD step with a single data point). Let us consider the total cost of ProxSkip-VR in the case of the LSVRG estimator: in each iteration we compute 1 stochastic gradient, and with probability q𝑞q we compute the exact gradient. We do not need to compute a second stochastic gradient since we can use memory and the relation yt+1=xtsubscript𝑦𝑡1subscript𝑥𝑡y_{t+1}=x_{t}. The total cost for ProxSkip-VR is equal to

Cost​(ProxSkip-VR)≔Tcomm.​(ProxSkip-VR)+δ​(q​m+(1−q)​τ+τ)​Titer​(ProxSkip-VR).≔CostProxSkip-VRsubscript𝑇comm.ProxSkip-VR𝛿𝑞𝑚1𝑞𝜏𝜏subscript𝑇iterProxSkip-VR\text{Cost}(\text{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}ProxSkip-VR}})\coloneqq T_{\text{comm.}}(\text{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}ProxSkip-VR}})+\delta\left(qm+(1-q)\tau+\tau\right)T_{\text{iter}}({\text{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}ProxSkip-VR}}}).

ProxSkip requires full/exact gradient computation at each iteration, so the total cost of ProxSkip is

Cost​(ProxSkip)≔Tcomm.​(ProxSkip)+δ​m​Titer​(ProxSkip).≔CostProxSkipsubscript𝑇comm.ProxSkip𝛿𝑚subscript𝑇iterProxSkip\text{Cost}(\text{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}ProxSkip}})\coloneqq T_{\text{comm.}}(\text{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}ProxSkip}})+\delta mT_{\text{iter}}({\text{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}ProxSkip}}}).

Using Theorems 6 and 9 and the value L​(τ)≔m−ττ​(m−1)​Lmax+m​(τ−1)τ​(m−1)​L≔𝐿𝜏𝑚𝜏𝜏𝑚1subscript𝐿𝑚𝜏1𝜏𝑚1𝐿L(\tau)\coloneqq\frac{m-\tau}{\tau(m-1)}L_{\max}+\frac{m(\tau-1)}{\tau(m-1)}L of the expected smoothness constant for sampling with minibatch size τ𝜏\tau uniformly at random, we get the following expression for the cost ratio, expressed as a function of δ𝛿\delta:

Cost ratio​(δ)≔Cost​(ProxSkip)Cost​(ProxSkip-VR)=μ​L+m​L​δμ​L​(τ)+(2​m​μ+(2​L​(τ)−2​μ)​τ)​δ.≔Cost ratio𝛿CostProxSkipCostProxSkip-VR𝜇𝐿𝑚𝐿𝛿𝜇𝐿𝜏2𝑚𝜇2𝐿𝜏2𝜇𝜏𝛿\displaystyle\text{Cost ratio}(\delta)\coloneqq\frac{\text{Cost}(\text{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}ProxSkip}})}{\text{Cost}(\text{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}ProxSkip-VR}})}=\frac{\sqrt{\mu L}+mL\delta}{\sqrt{\mu L(\tau)}+\left(2m\mu+(2L(\tau)-2\mu)\tau\right)\delta}. (15)

We can easily calculate the limits of this expression:

Cost ratio​(δ=0)=LL​(τ),Cost ratio​(δ→∞)=m​L2​(m​μ+(L​(τ)−μ)​τ).formulae-sequenceCost ratio𝛿0𝐿𝐿𝜏Cost ratio→𝛿𝑚𝐿2𝑚𝜇𝐿𝜏𝜇𝜏\displaystyle\text{Cost ratio}(\delta=0)=\sqrt{\frac{L}{L(\tau)}},\quad\quad\quad\text{Cost ratio}(\delta\to\infty)=\frac{mL}{2(m\mu+\left(L(\tau)-\mu\right)\tau)}.

Since L​(τ)≥L𝐿𝜏𝐿L(\tau)\geq L, the cost ratio is below 1 when δ=0𝛿0\delta=0 and τ<m𝜏𝑚\tau<m, which means that ProxSkip is better than ProxSkip-VR. This is to be expected since δ=0𝛿0\delta=0 means that we ignore the cost of local computation entirely, which offers advantage to the former method. On the other hand, the cost ratio is an increasing function of δ𝛿\delta, and often reaches the threshold of 1 with a small value of δ𝛿\delta; in 2 (second row), this threshold is reached for δ∈[10−6,10−5]𝛿superscript106superscript105\delta\in[10^{-6},10^{-5}] in all three plots.

In Figure 2 (second row), we depict the theoretical cost ratio according to (15) and the corresponding experimental cost ratio obtained by an actual run of both methods to achieve ε𝜀\varepsilon-accuracy, with ε=10−6𝜀superscript106\varepsilon=10^{-6} and ε=10−8𝜀superscript108\varepsilon=10^{-8}. Remarkably, the experimental results follows the same pattern as our theoretical prediction. The empirical curves appear lower because we use approximations for Lmaxsubscript𝐿L_{\max}, L𝐿L and μ𝜇\mu. As we can see, starting from δ=10−4𝛿superscript104\delta=10^{-4}, ProxSkip-VR starts to outperform ProxSkip. As δ𝛿\delta grows, the advantage of variance reduction embedded in ProxSkip-VR over vanilla ProxSkip grows. These results suggest that variance reduction is of practical utility in terms of the total cost, even for small values of δ𝛿\delta, and its effectiveness grows with δ𝛿\delta.

5.3 Additional experiments with ProxSkip-VR

We conduct further experiments to validate the efficiency of our proposed method ProxSkip-VR. We instantiate our variance reduction design with LSVRG and compare our method with several baselines across various datasets (w8a/a9a), different number of workers (10/20), and different batch sizes (16/32/64). All results in Figures 3, 4, 5, 6 show that ProxSkip-VR achieves linear convergence and outperforms the baselines.

5.4 Additional experiments of cost ratio of ProxSkip over ProxSkip-VR

Here we report on more experiments related to the total cost ratio of ProxSkip over ProxSkip-VR in Figures 7, 8, 9, 10. When GD is used as the subroutine, i.e., when ProxSkip-VR reduces to ProxSkip, the ratio is equal to one, and is depicted by the red horizontal dashed line. Any cost ratio above one means that ProxSkip-VR benefits over ProxSkip (e.g., a cost ratio of 101010 means 10×10\times speedup in favor of our method). As seen in the plots, acceleration of our method over ProxSkip is clearly visible, and improves as the local computation cost δ𝛿\delta per sample increases. For large values of δ𝛿\delta (i.e., δ≈10−1𝛿superscript101\delta\approx 10^{-1}), the acceleration can reach 20×20\times to 85×85\times. Note also that acceleration is more significant for small minibatch sizes. That is, it is better for τ=16𝜏16\tau=16 than for τ=32𝜏32\tau=32, which is better than in the τ=64𝜏64\tau=64 case. This means that in terms of total cost, it is beneficial for the workers to use smaller minibatch sizes, i.e., it is beneficial to be as far from the full batch regime employed by ProxSkip as possible.

5.5 Experiments with ProxSkip-HUB

In this work we introduced a new FL architecture: regional hubs connecting the clients to the server; see Section 4. For conceptual simplicity, and in order to facilitate fair comparison with ProxSkip-LSVRG, we assume that the number of hubs equals to the number of clients, and that each client owns a single datapoint only. We compare ProxSkip-HUB with ProxSkip-LSVRG to check whether communication compression leads to any benefits in terms of total costs. Theoretically, and similarly to our analysis in Section 5, the total cost for ProxSkip-LSVRG is

Cost​(ProxSkip-LSVRG)≔Tcomm.​(ProxSkip-LSVRG)+δ​(q​m+(1−q)​τ+τ)​Titer​(ProxSkip-LSVRG).≔CostProxSkip-LSVRGsubscript𝑇comm.ProxSkip-LSVRG𝛿𝑞𝑚1𝑞𝜏𝜏subscript𝑇iterProxSkip-LSVRG\text{Cost}(\text{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}ProxSkip-LSVRG}})\coloneqq T_{\text{comm.}}(\text{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}ProxSkip-LSVRG}})\\ +\delta\left(qm+(1-q)\tau+\tau\right)T_{\text{iter}}({\text{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}ProxSkip-LSVRG}}}).

Recall that we assume the communication cost from every worker/hub to the master is equal to 1, and the computation cost per sample is equal to δ𝛿\delta. Here we generalize to the multi-level structure. We assume that the communication cost from every client to hub is equal to δ′superscript𝛿′\delta^{\prime}. We choose the Rand-k𝑘k sparsification for ProxSkip-HUB; this compressor selects k𝑘k-entries of the gradient vector, uniformly at random from the full d𝑑d-dimensional gradient. The total cost of ProxSkip-HUB is

Cost​(ProxSkip-HUB)CostProxSkip-HUB\displaystyle\text{Cost}(\text{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}ProxSkip-HUB}}) :=Tcomm.​(ProxSkip-HUB)assignabsentsubscript𝑇comm.ProxSkip-HUB\displaystyle:=T_{\text{comm.}}(\text{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}ProxSkip-HUB}}) (16)
+δ′​(q​m+kd​((1−q)​τ+τ))​Titer​(ProxSkip-HUB).superscript𝛿′𝑞𝑚𝑘𝑑1𝑞𝜏𝜏subscript𝑇iterProxSkip-HUB\displaystyle\quad+\delta^{\prime}\left(qm+\frac{k}{d}\left((1-q)\tau+\tau\right)\right)T_{\text{iter}}(\text{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0.09765625,0.09765625}ProxSkip-HUB}}).

Our experimental results are summarized Figure 11; we use the values δ=δ​’=10−2𝛿𝛿’superscript102\delta=\delta\textquoteright=10^{-2}. Clearly, and thanks to communication compression, ProxSkip-HUB has benefit in terms of the total cost compared to ProxSkip-LSVRG, and can reach up to three degrees of magnitude!

Appendix A Basic Facts

A.1 Bregman divergence, L𝐿L-smoothness and μ𝜇\mu-strong convexity

The Bregman divergence of a differentiable function f:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is defined by

Df​(x,y):=f​(x)−f​(y)−⟨∇f​(y),x−y⟩.assignsubscript𝐷𝑓𝑥𝑦𝑓𝑥𝑓𝑦∇𝑓𝑦𝑥𝑦\displaystyle D_{f}(x,y):=f(x)-f(y)-\langle\nabla f(y),x-y\rangle. (17)

It is easy to see that

⟨∇f​(x)−∇f​(y),x−y⟩=Df​(x,y)+Df​(y,x),∀x,y∈ℝd.formulae-sequence∇𝑓𝑥∇𝑓𝑦𝑥𝑦subscript𝐷𝑓𝑥𝑦subscript𝐷𝑓𝑦𝑥for-all𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑\displaystyle\langle\nabla f(x)-\nabla f(y),x-y\rangle=D_{f}(x,y)+D_{f}(y,x),\quad\forall x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (18)

For an L𝐿L-smooth and μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex function f:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}, we have

μ2​‖x−y‖2≤Df​(x,y)≤L2​‖x−y‖2,∀x,y∈ℝdformulae-sequence𝜇2superscriptnorm𝑥𝑦2subscript𝐷𝑓𝑥𝑦𝐿2superscriptnorm𝑥𝑦2for-all𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑\displaystyle\frac{\mu}{2}\|x-y\|^{2}\leq D_{f}(x,y)\leq\frac{L}{2}\|x-y\|^{2},\quad\forall x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d} (19)

and

12​L​‖∇f​(x)−∇f​(y)‖2≤Df​(x,y)≤12​μ​‖∇f​(x)−∇f​(y)‖2,∀x,y∈ℝd.formulae-sequence12𝐿superscriptnorm∇𝑓𝑥∇𝑓𝑦2subscript𝐷𝑓𝑥𝑦12𝜇superscriptnorm∇𝑓𝑥∇𝑓𝑦2for-all𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑\displaystyle\frac{1}{2L}\|\nabla f(x)-\nabla f(y)\|^{2}\leq D_{f}(x,y)\leq\frac{1}{2\mu}\|\nabla f(x)-\nabla f(y)\|^{2},\quad\forall x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (20)

A.2 Firm-nonexpansiveness of the proximity operator

Given ψ:ℝd→ℝ:𝜓→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝ\psi:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}, we define ψ∗​(y):=supx∈ℝd{⟨x,y⟩−ψ​(x)}assignsuperscript𝜓𝑦subscriptsupremum𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑𝑥𝑦𝜓𝑥\psi^{*}(y):=\sup_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\{\langle x,y\rangle-\psi(x)\} to be its Fenchel conjugate. The proximity operator of ψ∗superscript𝜓\psi^{*} satisfies for any τ>0𝜏0\tau>0

if ​u=proxτ​ψ∗⁡(y), then u∈y−τ​∂ψ∗​(u).formulae-sequenceif 𝑢subscriptprox𝜏superscript𝜓𝑦 then 𝑢𝑦𝜏superscript𝜓𝑢\displaystyle\text{ if }u=\operatorname{prox}_{\tau\psi^{*}}(y),\quad\text{ then }\quad u\in y-\tau\partial\psi^{*}(u). (21)

If Assumption 3 is satisfied, then firm nonexpansiveness of the proximity operator implies [Mishchenko et al., 2022] that

‖proxγp​ψ⁡(x)−proxγp​ψ⁡(y)‖2+‖(x−proxγp​ψ⁡(x))−(y−proxγp​ψ⁡(y))‖2≤‖x−y‖2,superscriptnormsubscriptprox𝛾𝑝𝜓𝑥subscriptprox𝛾𝑝𝜓𝑦2superscriptnorm𝑥subscriptprox𝛾𝑝𝜓𝑥𝑦subscriptprox𝛾𝑝𝜓𝑦2superscriptnorm𝑥𝑦2\displaystyle\left\|\operatorname{prox}_{\frac{\gamma}{p}\psi}(x)-\operatorname{prox}_{\frac{\gamma}{p}\psi}(y)\right\|^{2}+\left\|\left(x-\operatorname{prox}_{\frac{\gamma}{p}\psi}(x)\right)-\left(y-\operatorname{prox}_{\frac{\gamma}{p}\psi}(y)\right)\right\|^{2}\leq\|x-y\|^{2}, (22)

for all x,y∈ℝd𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and any γ,p>0𝛾𝑝0\gamma,p>0.

A.3 Young’s inequality

For any two vectors a,b∈ℝd𝑎𝑏superscriptℝ𝑑a,b\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, we have

‖a+b‖2≤2​‖a‖2+2​‖b‖2.superscriptnorm𝑎𝑏22superscriptnorm𝑎22superscriptnorm𝑏2\|a+b\|^{2}\leq 2\|a\|^{2}+2\|b\|^{2}. (23)

A.4 Jensen’s inequality

For a convex function h:ℝd←ℝ:ℎ←superscriptℝ𝑑ℝh:\mathbb{R}^{d}\leftarrow\mathbb{R} and any vectors x1,…,xn∈ℝdsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛superscriptℝ𝑑x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, we have

h​(1n​∑i=1nxi)≤1n​∑i=1nh​(xi).ℎ1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛ℎsubscript𝑥𝑖\displaystyle h\left(\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}\right)\leq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}h\left(x_{i}\right). (24)

‖1n​∑i=1nyi‖2≤1n​∑i=1n‖yi‖2.superscriptnorm1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑦𝑖21𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptnormsubscript𝑦𝑖2\displaystyle\left\|\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}y_{i}\right\|^{2}\leq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|y_{i}\right\|^{2}. (25)

B.2 Main lemma

This lemma allows us to obtain a useful recursion for variance-reduced stochastic estimators used in our ProxSkip-VR algorithm.

Lemma 2.

Let Assumptions 2 and 4 hold. Then the iterates of ProxSkip-VR satisfy

𝔼​[‖w^t−w⋆‖2]≤(1−γ​μ)​‖xt−x⋆‖2−2​γ​Df​(xt,x⋆)​(1−γ​A)+γ2​B​σt+γ2​C.𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript^𝑤𝑡subscript𝑤⋆21𝛾𝜇superscriptnormsubscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆22𝛾subscript𝐷𝑓subscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆1𝛾𝐴superscript𝛾2𝐵subscript𝜎𝑡superscript𝛾2𝐶\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\|\hat{w}_{t}-w_{\star}\|^{2}\right]\leq(1-\gamma\mu)\|x_{t}-x_{\star}\|^{2}-2\gamma D_{f}(x_{t},x_{\star})\left(1-\gamma A\right)+\gamma^{2}B\sigma_{t}+\gamma^{2}C.
Proof.

We start from the definitions of the auxiliary sequence w^tsubscript^𝑤𝑡\hat{w}_{t} (see (26)):

‖w^t−w⋆‖2superscriptnormsubscript^𝑤𝑡subscript𝑤⋆2\displaystyle\|\hat{w}_{t}-w_{\star}\|^{2} =(​26​)italic-(26italic-)\displaystyle\overset{\eqref{eq:seqs}}{=} ‖xt−γ​g^t−(x⋆−γ​∇f​(x⋆))‖2superscriptnormsubscript𝑥𝑡𝛾subscript^𝑔𝑡subscript𝑥⋆𝛾∇𝑓subscript𝑥⋆2\displaystyle\|x_{t}-\gamma\hat{g}_{t}-(x_{\star}-\gamma\nabla f(x_{\star}))\|^{2} (39)
=\displaystyle= ‖(xt−x⋆)−γ​(g^t−∇f​(x⋆))‖2superscriptnormsubscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆𝛾subscript^𝑔𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝑥⋆2\displaystyle\|(x_{t}-x_{\star})-\gamma(\hat{g}_{t}-\nabla f(x_{\star}))\|^{2}
=\displaystyle= ‖xt−x⋆‖2−2​γ​⟨xt−x⋆,g^t−∇f​(x⋆)⟩+γ2​‖g^t−∇f​(x⋆)‖2.superscriptnormsubscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆22𝛾subscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆subscript^𝑔𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝑥⋆superscript𝛾2superscriptnormsubscript^𝑔𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝑥⋆2\displaystyle\|x_{t}-x_{\star}\|^{2}-2\gamma\left\langle x_{t}-x_{\star},\hat{g}_{t}-\nabla f(x_{\star})\right\rangle+\gamma^{2}\|\hat{g}_{t}-\nabla f(x_{\star})\|^{2}.

Taking expectation in (39) and using unbiasedness of g^tsubscript^𝑔𝑡\hat{g}_{t} (see (5) in Assumption 4), we get

𝔼​[‖w^t−w⋆‖2]​=(​39​)+(​5​)​‖xt−x⋆‖2−2​γ​⟨xt−x⋆,∇f​(xt)−∇f​(x⋆)⟩+γ2​𝔼​[‖g^t−∇f​(x⋆)‖2].𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript^𝑤𝑡subscript𝑤⋆2italic-(39italic-)italic-(5italic-)superscriptnormsubscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆22𝛾subscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆∇𝑓subscript𝑥𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝑥⋆superscript𝛾2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript^𝑔𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝑥⋆2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\|\hat{w}_{t}-w_{\star}\|^{2}\right]\overset{\eqref{32}+\eqref{eq:unbiased}}{=}\|x_{t}-x_{\star}\|^{2}-2\gamma\left\langle x_{t}-x_{\star},\nabla f(x_{t})-\nabla f(x_{\star})\right\rangle+\gamma^{2}\mathbb{E}\left[\|\hat{g}_{t}-\nabla f(x_{\star})\|^{2}\right]. (40)

𝔼​[‖w^t−w⋆‖2]≤(1−γ​μ)​‖xt−x⋆‖2−2​γ​Df​(xt,x⋆)+γ2​𝔼​[‖g^t−∇f​(x⋆)‖2].𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript^𝑤𝑡subscript𝑤⋆21𝛾𝜇superscriptnormsubscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆22𝛾subscript𝐷𝑓subscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆superscript𝛾2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript^𝑔𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝑥⋆2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\|\hat{w}_{t}-w_{\star}\|^{2}\right]\leq(1-\gamma\mu)\|x_{t}-x_{\star}\|^{2}-2\gamma D_{f}(x_{t},x_{\star})+\gamma^{2}\mathbb{E}\left[\|\hat{g}_{t}-\nabla f(x_{\star})\|^{2}\right]. 𝔼​[‖g^t−∇f​(x⋆)‖2]≤2​A​Df​(xt,x⋆)+B​σt+C.𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript^𝑔𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝑥⋆22𝐴subscript𝐷𝑓subscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆𝐵subscript𝜎𝑡𝐶\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\|\hat{g}_{t}-\nabla f(x_{\star})\|^{2}\right]\leq 2AD_{f}(x_{t},x_{\star})+B\sigma_{t}+C. (42)

≤(1−γ​μ)​‖xt−x⋆‖2−2​γ​Df​(xt,x⋆)​(1−γ​A)+γ2​B​σt+γ2​C,absent1𝛾𝜇superscriptnormsubscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆22𝛾subscript𝐷𝑓subscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆1𝛾𝐴superscript𝛾2𝐵subscript𝜎𝑡superscript𝛾2𝐶\displaystyle\leq(1-\gamma\mu)\|x_{t}-x_{\star}\|^{2}-2\gamma D_{f}(x_{t},x_{\star})\left(1-\gamma A\right)+\gamma^{2}B\sigma_{t}+\gamma^{2}C, (43)

Proof.

Let us denote β≔B+W​B~W≔𝛽𝐵𝑊~𝐵𝑊\beta\coloneqq\frac{B+W\tilde{B}}{W}. In order to obtain a contraction, we need to have β<1𝛽1\beta<1, which is satisfied when W>B1−B~𝑊𝐵1~𝐵W>\frac{B}{1-\tilde{B}}, and we get

𝔼​[Ψt+1]𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΨ𝑡1\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\Psi_{t+1}\right] ≤\displaystyle\leq (1−γ​μ)​‖xt−x⋆‖2+γ2​W​σt​β+γ2​(C+W​C~)+(1−p2)​γ2p2​‖ht−h⋆‖21𝛾𝜇superscriptnormsubscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆2superscript𝛾2𝑊subscript𝜎𝑡𝛽superscript𝛾2𝐶𝑊~𝐶1superscript𝑝2superscript𝛾2superscript𝑝2superscriptnormsubscriptℎ𝑡subscriptℎ⋆2\displaystyle(1-\gamma\mu)\|x_{t}-x_{\star}\|^{2}+\gamma^{2}W\sigma_{t}\beta+\gamma^{2}(C+W\tilde{C})+(1-p^{2})\frac{\gamma^{2}}{p^{2}}\|h_{t}-h_{\star}\|^{2} (45)
≤\displaystyle\leq max⁡(1−p2,β,1−γ​μ)​Ψt+γ2​(C+W​C~).1superscript𝑝2𝛽1𝛾𝜇subscriptΨ𝑡superscript𝛾2𝐶𝑊~𝐶\displaystyle\max\left(1-p^{2},\beta,1-\gamma\mu\right)\Psi_{t}+\gamma^{2}(C+W\tilde{C}).

Finally, using the tower property of expectation and unrolling recursion (45), we get

𝔼​[ΨT]≤max⁡{(1−γ​μ)T,βT,(1−p2)T}​Ψ0+(C+W​C~)​γ2min⁡{γ​μ,p2,1−β}.𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΨ𝑇superscript1𝛾𝜇𝑇superscript𝛽𝑇superscript1superscript𝑝2𝑇subscriptΨ0𝐶𝑊~𝐶superscript𝛾2𝛾𝜇superscript𝑝21𝛽\mathbb{E}\left[\Psi_{T}\right]\leq\max\left\{(1-\gamma\mu)^{T},\beta^{T},(1-p^{2})^{T}\right\}\Psi_{0}+\frac{\left(C+W\tilde{C}\right)\gamma^{2}}{\min\left\{\gamma\mu,p^{2},1-\beta\right\}}.

∎

Appendix C Examples of Methods Without Variance Reduction

C.1 Proof of Theorem 6 (GD estimator)

Proof.

Let us show that GD estimator (g^t=∇f​(xt))subscript^𝑔𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝑥𝑡(\hat{g}_{t}=\nabla f(x_{t})) satisfies Assumption 4

𝔼​[‖g^t−∇f​(x⋆)‖2]=‖∇f​(xt)−∇f​(x⋆)‖2≤(​19​)2​L​Df​(xt,x⋆).𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript^𝑔𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝑥⋆2superscriptnorm∇𝑓subscript𝑥𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝑥⋆2superscriptitalic-(19italic-)2𝐿subscript𝐷𝑓subscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\|\hat{g}_{t}-\nabla f(x_{\star})\|^{2}\right]=\|\nabla f(x_{t})-\nabla f(x_{\star})\|^{2}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\eqref{eq:smooth-norms}}}{{\leq}}2LD_{f}(x_{t},x_{\star}).

This means that Assumption 4 is satisfied with the following constant:

A=L,B=0,C=0,A~=0,B~=0,C~=0,σt≡0.formulae-sequence𝐴𝐿formulae-sequence𝐵0formulae-sequence𝐶0formulae-sequence~𝐴0formulae-sequence~𝐵0formulae-sequence~𝐶0subscript𝜎𝑡0\displaystyle A=L,\quad B=0,\quad C=0,\quad\tilde{A}=0,\quad\tilde{B}=0,\quad\tilde{C}=0,\quad\sigma_{t}\equiv 0.

Applying Theorem 5 leads to final recursion:

𝔼​[ΨT]≤max⁡{(1−γ​μ)T,(1−p2)T}​Ψ0,𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΨ𝑇superscript1𝛾𝜇𝑇superscript1superscript𝑝2𝑇subscriptΨ0\mathbb{E}\left[\Psi_{T}\right]\leq\max\left\{(1-\gamma\mu)^{T},(1-p^{2})^{T}\right\}\Psi_{0}, (46)

T≥max⁡{1γ​μ,1p2}​log⁡1ε⟹𝔼​[ΨT]≤ε​Ψ0.formulae-sequence𝑇1𝛾𝜇1superscript𝑝21𝜀⟹𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΨ𝑇𝜀subscriptΨ0T\geq\max\left\{\frac{1}{\gamma\mu},\frac{1}{p^{2}}\right\}\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad\mathbb{E}\left[\Psi_{T}\right]\leq\varepsilon\Psi_{0}. (47)

Then the communication complexity is equal to

p​T≥max⁡{pγ​μ,1p}​log⁡1ε.𝑝𝑇𝑝𝛾𝜇1𝑝1𝜀pT\geq\max\left\{\frac{p}{\gamma\mu},\frac{1}{p}\right\}\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}. (48)

p=μL=1κ𝑝𝜇𝐿1𝜅p=\sqrt{\frac{\mu}{L}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\kappa}} (49)

Finally, the iteration complexity and communication complexity have the following form:

T𝑇\displaystyle T ≥max⁡{1γ​μ,1p2}​log⁡1ε=κ​log⁡1ε,absent1𝛾𝜇1superscript𝑝21𝜀𝜅1𝜀\displaystyle\geq\max\left\{\frac{1}{\gamma\mu},\frac{1}{p^{2}}\right\}\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}=\kappa\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}, (50)

∎

This recovers the result obtained by Mishchenko et al. [2022].

C.2 Proof of Theorem 8 (SGD estimator)

𝔼​[ΨT]≤max⁡{(1−γ​μ)T,(1−p2)T}​Ψ0+γ2​2​V​a​r​(g​(x⋆,ξ))min⁡{γ​μ,p2}.𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΨ𝑇superscript1𝛾𝜇𝑇superscript1superscript𝑝2𝑇subscriptΨ0superscript𝛾22Var𝑔subscript𝑥⋆𝜉𝛾𝜇superscript𝑝2\mathbb{E}\left[\Psi_{T}\right]\leq\max\left\{(1-\gamma\mu)^{T},(1-p^{2})^{T}\right\}\Psi_{0}+\gamma^{2}\frac{2{\rm Var}(g(x_{\star},\xi))}{\min\left\{\gamma\mu,p^{2}\right\}}. (53)

In order to minimize the number of prox evaluations, whatever the choice of γ𝛾\gamma will be, we choose the smallest probability p𝑝p which does not lead to any degradation of the rate min⁡{γ​μ,p2}.𝛾𝜇superscript𝑝2\min\{\gamma\mu,p^{2}\}. That is, we choose p=γ​μ𝑝𝛾𝜇p=\sqrt{\gamma\mu}. The first term on the right-hand side of (53) can be bounded as follows:

T≥1γ​μ​log⁡(2​Ψ0ε)⟹(1−γ​μ)T​Ψ0≤ε2.formulae-sequence𝑇1𝛾𝜇2subscriptΨ0𝜀⟹superscript1𝛾𝜇𝑇subscriptΨ0𝜀2T\geq\frac{1}{\gamma\mu}\log\left(\frac{2\Psi_{0}}{\varepsilon}\right)\quad\Longrightarrow\quad(1-\gamma\mu)^{T}\Psi_{0}\leq\frac{\varepsilon}{2}.

The second term on the right-hand side of (53) can be bounded as follows:

γ≤ε​μ2​C⟹γ​Cμ≤ε2.formulae-sequence𝛾𝜀𝜇2𝐶⟹𝛾𝐶𝜇𝜀2\gamma\leq\frac{\varepsilon\mu}{2C}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad\frac{\gamma C}{\mu}\leq\frac{\varepsilon}{2}.

We choose the largest stepsize consistent with bounds γ≤ε​μ2​C𝛾𝜀𝜇2𝐶\gamma\leq\frac{\varepsilon\mu}{2C} and γ≤1A𝛾1𝐴\gamma\leq\frac{1}{A}:

γ=min⁡{1A,ε​μ2​C}.𝛾1𝐴𝜀𝜇2𝐶\displaystyle\gamma=\min\left\{\frac{1}{A},\frac{\varepsilon\mu}{2C}\right\}.

Using this stepsizem we get the following iteration and (expected) communication complexities:

T≥max⁡{Aμ,2​Cε​μ2}​log⁡(2​Ψ0ε),p​T≥max⁡{Aμ,2​Cε​μ2}​log⁡(2​Ψ0ε).formulae-sequence𝑇𝐴𝜇2𝐶𝜀superscript𝜇22subscriptΨ0𝜀𝑝𝑇𝐴𝜇2𝐶𝜀superscript𝜇22subscriptΨ0𝜀\displaystyle T\geq\max\left\{\frac{A}{\mu},\frac{2C}{\varepsilon\mu^{2}}\right\}\log\left(\frac{2\Psi_{0}}{\varepsilon}\right),\qquad pT\geq\max\left\{\sqrt{\frac{A}{\mu}},\sqrt{\frac{2C}{\varepsilon\mu^{2}}}\right\}\log\left(\frac{2\Psi_{0}}{\varepsilon}\right).

This recovers the result obtained by Mishchenko et al. [2022]. ∎

Appendix D Analysis of ProxSkip-HUB

In this section we provide analysis of the new algorithm ProxSkip-HUB, which works for the new FL formulation described in Section 4. The pseudocode is presented in Algorithm 2.

D.1 Lemma for minibatch sampling

Fix a minibatch size τ∈{1,2,…,n}𝜏12…𝑛\tau\in\{1,2,\ldots,n\} and let 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}_{t} be a random subset of {1,2,…,n}12…𝑛\{1,2,\ldots,n\} of size τ𝜏\tau, chosen uniformly at random. Define the gradient estimator via

g​(x)≔1τ​∑j∈𝒮t∇ϕ~j​(x)≔𝑔𝑥1𝜏subscript𝑗subscript𝒮𝑡∇subscript~italic-ϕ𝑗𝑥g(x)\coloneqq\frac{1}{\tau}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\nabla\widetilde{\phi}_{j}(x) (54)
Lemma 3.

The gradient estimator g​(x)𝑔𝑥g(x) defined in (54) is unbiased. If we further assume that n≥2𝑛2n\geq 2, ϕ~jsubscript~italic-ϕ𝑗\widetilde{\phi}_{j} is convex and Ljsubscript𝐿𝑗L_{j}-smooth for all j𝑗j, and f𝑓f is L𝐿L-smooth, then

𝔼​[‖g​(xt)−g​(x⋆)‖2]≤2​L​(τ)​Df​(xt,x⋆),𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝑔subscript𝑥𝑡𝑔subscript𝑥⋆22𝐿𝜏subscript𝐷𝑓subscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\|g(x_{t})-g(x_{\star})\|^{2}\right]\leq 2L(\tau)D_{f}(x_{t},x_{\star}),

where

L​(τ)≔n−ττ​(n−1)​maxj⁡Lj+n​(τ−1)τ​(n−1)​L.≔𝐿𝜏𝑛𝜏𝜏𝑛1subscript𝑗subscript𝐿𝑗𝑛𝜏1𝜏𝑛1𝐿\displaystyle L(\tau)\coloneqq\frac{n-\tau}{\tau(n-1)}\max_{j}L_{j}+\frac{n(\tau-1)}{\tau(n-1)}L.

Applying Theorem 5 leads to the final result

𝔼​[ΨT]≤max⁡{(1−γ​μ)T,(1−p2)T,(1−q/2)T}​Ψ0,𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΨ𝑇superscript1𝛾𝜇𝑇superscript1superscript𝑝2𝑇superscript1𝑞2𝑇subscriptΨ0\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\Psi_{T}\right]\leq\max\left\{(1-\gamma\mu)^{T},(1-p^{2})^{T},\left(1-\nicefrac{{q}}{{2}}\right)^{T}\right\}\Psi_{0}, (74)

where the Lyapunov function is defined by

Ψt≔‖xt−x⋆‖2+γ2p2​‖ht−h⋆‖2+γ2​8q​(1+ωτ)​σt.≔subscriptΨ𝑡superscriptnormsubscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥⋆2superscript𝛾2superscript𝑝2superscriptnormsubscriptℎ𝑡subscriptℎ⋆2superscript𝛾28𝑞1𝜔𝜏subscript𝜎𝑡\Psi_{t}\coloneqq\|x_{t}-x_{\star}\|^{2}+\frac{\gamma^{2}}{p^{2}}\|h_{t}-h_{\star}\|^{2}+\gamma^{2}\frac{8}{q}\left(1+\frac{\omega}{\tau}\right)\sigma_{t}.

Let us set γ=1A+W​A~𝛾1𝐴𝑊~𝐴\gamma=\frac{1}{A+W\tilde{A}}, p=γ​μ𝑝𝛾𝜇p=\sqrt{\gamma\mu} and q=2​γ​μ𝑞2𝛾𝜇q=2\gamma\mu. Using the same proof as for ProxSkip in Section C.1 and L​(τ)≤Lmax𝐿𝜏subscript𝐿L(\tau)\leq L_{\max} we get communication and iteration complexities:

Tcomm.=𝒪​(Lmaxμ​(1+ωτ)​log⁡1ε),Titer.=𝒪​(Lmaxμ​(1+ωτ)​log⁡1ε).formulae-sequencesubscript𝑇comm.𝒪subscript𝐿𝜇1𝜔𝜏1𝜀subscript𝑇iter.𝒪subscript𝐿𝜇1𝜔𝜏1𝜀\displaystyle T_{\text{comm.}}=\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{L_{\max}}{\mu}\left(1+\frac{\omega}{\tau}\right)}\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right),\qquad T_{\text{iter.}}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{L_{\max}}{\mu}\left(1+\frac{\omega}{\tau}\right)\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right).

∎

If we use full participation τ=n𝜏𝑛\tau=n and q=1ω+1𝑞1𝜔1q=\frac{1}{\omega+1} and r​(x)≡0𝑟𝑥0r(x)\equiv 0 then we get the same rate as for DIANA [Mishchenko et al., 2019, Horváth et al., 2019b] and RAND-DIANA [Shulgin and Richtárik, 2021].

Appendix E Analysis of ProxSkip-LSVRG

The analysis of ProxSkip-LSVRG is almost the same to the analysis of ProxSkip-HUB, with one exception. We use a different sigma component:

σt=𝔼​[‖1τ​∑j∈𝒮t(∇ϕ~j​(yt)−∇ϕ~j​(x⋆))‖2].subscript𝜎𝑡𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm1𝜏subscript𝑗subscript𝒮𝑡∇subscript~italic-ϕ𝑗subscript𝑦𝑡∇subscript~italic-ϕ𝑗subscript𝑥⋆2\displaystyle\sigma_{t}=\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\frac{1}{\tau}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}(\nabla\widetilde{\phi}_{j}(y_{t})-\nabla\widetilde{\phi}_{j}(x_{\star}))\right\|^{2}\right]. (75)

Let us consider 𝔼​[‖g^t−∇f​(x⋆)‖2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript^𝑔𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝑥⋆2\mathbb{E}\left[\|\hat{g}_{t}-\nabla f(x_{\star})\|^{2}\right]:

𝔼​[‖g^t−∇f​(x⋆)‖2]=𝔼​[‖1τ​∑j∈St(∇ϕ~j​(xt)−∇ϕ~j​(yt))+∇f​(y)−∇f​(x⋆)‖2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript^𝑔𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝑥⋆2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm1𝜏subscript𝑗subscript𝑆𝑡∇subscript~italic-ϕ𝑗subscript𝑥𝑡∇subscript~italic-ϕ𝑗subscript𝑦𝑡∇𝑓𝑦∇𝑓subscript𝑥⋆2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\|\hat{g}_{t}-\nabla f(x_{\star})\|^{2}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\frac{1}{\tau}\sum_{j\in S_{t}}\left(\nabla\widetilde{\phi}_{j}(x_{t})-\nabla\widetilde{\phi}_{j}(y_{t})\right)+\nabla f(y)-\nabla f(x_{\star})\right\|^{2}\right] (76)

Using (D.2) we have
